subject: https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/people/cp10343
object:
about 1840 - moved to Leicester 
by 1846 - established himself as a "fancy hosiery manufacturer" in Humberstone Gate, Leicester
1849 - owned an India Rubber business, Turner and Pegg in Hill Street, Leicester  
1855 - listed as being an elastic web manufacturer in Belgrave Gate, Leicaester.  Several patents and a boom in business led to the construction of a new factory on King Richards Road entitled 'Bow Bridge Works'.

subject: https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/people/cp15729
object: William Carey set up his own business about 1790 and became noted for his astronomical and other scientific instruments. He soon turned his attention to the making of terrestrial and celestial globes and the firm of Cary became one of the foremost in this field during the first half of the 19th century.

subject: https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/people/cp10269
object:
1739 - Born in Corney, Cumbria, England; Apprenticed to his Uncle John Troughton 
1764 - traded at Surrey St., Strand, London 
1768-71 - traded at Crown Court, Fleet St., London
1771-78 - traded at 17 Dean St., Fetter Lane, London 
1778-82 - traded at 1 Queen's Sq., Bartholomew Close, London 
1782 - purchased the business of Benjamin Cole  
1782-1788 - traded at the sign of the Orrery, 136 Fleet St, London, England.  
1788-1804 - in partnership as J & E Troughton, with brother Edward Troughton (1756-1835)

subject: https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/people/cp1072
object: 1805 - indentured for seven years to Riebau as an apprentice bookbinder.  1813 - became laboratory assistant at the Royal Institution.  1821 - discovered electromagnetic rotations.  1825 -  discovered a new compound of hydrogen and carbon which he named bicarburet of hydrogen later renamed benzine.  1826 - establiashed the Christmas lectures for children at the Royal Institution.  1829 - secured the professorship of chemistry at the Royal Military Academy.  1831 - discovered electromagnetic induction.  1836 - built what is now known as the ‘Faraday cage’.  1842 - accepted membership of the Prussian order of merit.  1855 - accepted membership of the French Légion d'honneur.  1866 - received the Albert medal from the Society of Arts.

https://collection.sciencemuseumgroup.org.uk/people/cp15194
object: Son of a spinning mill owner, Newton Wilson opened his own engineering workshop at Manchester in 1854, and his first London shop in 1857.  Amongst many objects sold was a Boudoir sewing machine from America, to which he gave great publicity.  In 1866 N.W. started to produce his own brand of sewing machines, i.e. Queen Mab and Cleopatra.  In 1867 he moved his manufacturing to St. Georges Foundry, Birmingham.  His work force and design team included people later to become famous in other industries: James Starley (cycles), William Singer (cycles and cars), William Hillman (sewing machines), A.G. Baylis (needles) and Herbert (sewing machines and machine tools).  From 1890 he devoted his time to writing a History of the Sewing Machine which he never finished.  In 1874 he discovered the Thomas Saint patent of 1790 and built a replica, which was donated to the Science Museum (inv. no. 1894-190).
